query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
7 Ma quel padre verace, che s’accorse 8 del timido voler che non s’apriva, 9 parlando, di parlare ardir mi porse.
query.result:
**English:**
7 But that true father, who perceived 8 the timid will that did not open itself up, 9 by speaking, gave me the courage to speak.
**Cornish:**
7 Mes an tas gwir, neb a wra dhesempys marow ow tos ow tenewen 8 an volonte omdhiskwedhys a nag ostyth y honan, 9 ow tos ow tenewen, ow tos ow tenewen a wra dhesempys marow ow tos ow tenewen an gallos rag ow tos ow tenewen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Ond’ io: «Maestro, il mio veder s’avviva 11 sì nel tuo lume, ch’io discerno chiaro 12 quanto la tua ragion parta o descriva.
query.result:
**English:**
10 And I said: "Master, my sight is quickened 11 so much by your light that I clearly discern 12 whatever your reason sets forth or describes.
**Cornish:**
10 Ha my a leveris: "Mestron, ow gweles a wra vyw 11 yn dha golon, henna a wel ow tos ow klares 12 pyth yw an reson dha a leveris po a dhiskrivyas."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Però ti prego, dolce padre caro, 14 che mi dimostri amore, a cui reduci 15 ogne buono operare e ’l suo contraro».
query.result:
**English:**
13 But I beg you, dear and gentle father, 14 to show me love, to which you bring back 15 every good deed and its opposite.
**Cornish:**
13 Mes ow pyth a leveris, ker tas ow thas ker, 14 dhe wiskya karantegeth dhe'gas, dhe'gas a wra 15 pub tra ober da ha'y gwithrans."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 «Drizza», disse, «ver’ me l’agute luci 17 de lo ’ntelletto, e fieti manifesto 18 l’error de’ ciechi che si fanno duci.
query.result:
**English:**
16 "Turn," he said, "the keen lights of your intellect 17 toward me, and the error of the blind 18 who make themselves leaders will be clear to you.
**Cornish:**
16 "Treylya," leveris ef, "an golon gwitha dhe'gas 17 dhe'gas a wra kler dhe feth an erer 18 a'n dall a wra aga ledyoryon."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
19 L’animo, ch’è creato ad amar presto, 20 ad ogne cosa è mobile che piace, 21 tosto che dal piacere in atto è desto.
query.result:
**English:**
19 The soul, which is created to love quickly, 20 is drawn to everything that pleases it, 21 as soon as it is awakened to pleasure by an act.
**Cornish:**
19 An eneval, a veu cresyes dhe karantegeth, 20 dhe pub tra ober a wra ow karantegeth, 21 pub tra ober a wra ow karantegeth, 21 pub tra ober a wra ow karantegeth, 21 kelmys wosa ow tos ow karantegeth.

**English:**
22 Your apprehensive nature, to be true, 23 draws intention, and within you unfolds it, 24 so that it makes the soul turn to it;
25 and if, turned, it bends towards it, 26 that bending is love, that is the nature 27 that binds itself to you anew for pleasure.
**Cornish:**
22 Yowrthvosapprensiva,ragbodhavosgwir, 23awerthintensioun,hagynnowydhyworth, 24hagan an enevala wra dha'ganhenwel.
25 Hagy,gwra,ynwedhynedhi, 26 an wra gwra yw karanteth, an wra honan yw naturel, 27 a wra a wra'gan lowena nowydh yn y gila.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Poi, come ’l foco movesi in altura 29 per la sua forma ch’è nata a salire 30 là dove più in sua matera dura,
31 così l’animo preso entra in disire, 32 ch’è moto spiritale, e mai non posa 33 fin che la cosa amata il fa gioire.
query.result:
**English:**
28 Then, just as fire rises upwards 29 because of its form, which is born to rise, 30 to where it lasts longer in its matter,
31 so the captured soul enters into desire, 32 which is a spiritual motion, and never rests 33 until the beloved thing makes it rejoice.
**Cornish:**
28 Wosa,vel an tan a wra'n movyas yn ughella, 29 rag an furv a wra genys dhe vos dhe sevel, 30 le may hy a wra moy dhe bys yn y vater.
31 Yn par an eneval a wra kemeres a wra mos dhe desira, 32 a wra movyas sperys, ha neb vyth a wra pos, 33 bys may an pyth karesek a wra'n gwre gwella.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 Ed elli a me: «Quanto ragion qui vede, 47 dir ti poss’ io; da indi in là t’aspetta 48 pur a Beatrice, ch’è opra di fede.
query.result:
**English:**
46 And he to me: "As much as reason sees here, 47 I can tell you; from there on, you must wait 48 for Beatrice, who is a work of faith.
**Cornish:**
46 Ha henna dhe'm: "Pyth yw resen a wra gweles ama, 47 yth alla'm dywedhes dhe'th; a-wosa henna, gwra'th aspedya 48 rag Beatrice, a wra ober a fydh."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Ogne forma sustanzïal, che setta 50 è da matera ed è con lei unita, 51 specifica vertute ha in sé colletta,
52 la qual sanza operar non è sentita, 53 né si dimostra mai che per effetto, 54 come per verdi fronde in pianta vita.
query.result:
**English:**
49 Every substantial form, which is derived 50 from matter and is united with it, 51 has a specific virtue collected in itself,
52 which is not perceived without acting, 53 nor does it ever show itself except through its effect, 54 like the life in a plant through its green leaves.
**Cornish:**
49 Pub furv a wra substans, a wra settys 50 a-dhyworth mater ha unys gansti, 51 a wra vertu a-bennak ynni gollettys,
52 henna na wra teves mar nyns yw oberys, 53 na wra dallethys byth mes a-dhyworth effek, 54 vel an gwydh gwer yn plansa byw.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Però, là onde vegna lo ’ntelletto 56 de le prime notizie, omo non sape, 57 e de’ primi appetibili l’affetto,
58 che sono in voi sì come studio in ape 59 di far lo mele; e questa prima voglia 60 merto di lode o di biasmo non cape.
query.result:
**English:**
55 But, whence the intellect comes to have 56 the first notions, man does not know, 57 and the affection for the first desirable things,
58 which are in you like the instinct in bees 59 to make honey; and this first desire 60 is not capable of praise or blame.
**Cornish:**
55 Mes, le mayth ow tos an intellekt 56 a'n kynsa nowodhow, den a wydh gowsys, 57 ha'n kynsa appetit an affeckt,
58 nebes yw ynnowi kepareth avel gwenyn 59 rag gwul an mel; ha hemma kynsa hwiw 60 nyns yw kablus a ros po kemmys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Or perché a questa ogn’ altra si raccoglia, 62 innata v’è la virtù che consiglia, 63 e de l’assenso de’ tener la soglia.
query.result:
**English:**
61 Now, because every other desire gathers to this one, 62 there is innate in you the virtue that counsels, 63 and of consent to hold the threshold.
**Cornish:**
61 Mes rag dhe'm hemma pub tra re beu, 62 genys yw ynnowi an virtudes a gonsel, 63 ha'n assens dhe gresi an fordh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Quest’ è ’l principio là onde si piglia 65 ragion di meritare in voi, secondo 66 che buoni e rei amori accoglie e viglia.
query.result:
**English:**
64 This is the principle from which is taken 65 the reason for meriting in you, according to 66 how it welcomes and watches over good and evil loves.
**Cornish:**
64 Hemma yw an prensipel le mayth ow kemer 65 resen a veriti ynnowi, herwydh 66 pyth yw da ha drog karantegow a wel ha gwyli.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Color che ragionando andaro al fondo, 68 s’accorser d’esta innata libertate; 69 però moralità lasciaro al mondo.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Those who, reasoning, went to the bottom of it, 68 realized this innate freedom; 69 therefore they left morality to the world.
**Cornish:**
67 Nebes a resona a-wrug dhe'n fordh, 68 a welas hemma frankis genys; 69 rag henna i hedhas moralita dhe'n bys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Onde, poniam che di necessitate 71 surga ogne amor che dentro a voi s’accende, 72 di ritenerlo è in voi la podestate.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Hence, let us suppose that of necessity 71 every love that is kindled within you arises, 72 the power to restrain it is in you.
**Cornish:**
70 Rag henna, leverel mayth a-wrug 71 pub karanteth a wra dhe'nnowi ynnowi, 72 an gallu dhe'nnowi yw dhe'gres.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 La nobile virtù Beatrice intende 74 per lo libero arbitrio, e però guarda 75 che l’abbi a mente, s’a parlar ten prende».
query.result:
**English:**
73 The noble virtue Beatrice means 74 by free will, and therefore see 75 that you keep it in mind, if you undertake to speak».
**Cornish:**
73 An virtudes nobyl, Beatris a styr 74 rag an frankis erbi, ha rag henna gwel 75 ow pokoes ynnowi, pub tra veth dhe leverel».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Ma questa sonnolenza mi fu tolta 89 subitamente da gente che dopo 90 le nostre spalle a noi era già volta.
query.result:
**English:**
88 But this drowsiness was taken from me 89 suddenly by people who behind 90 our backs had already turned towards us.
**Cornish:**
88 Mes hemma hunyans a veu kemer dhym 89 yn subit drefennow a wra ow holya 90 a-dhelerow dhe'n ni a wra ow trohya.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 E quale Ismeno già vide e Asopo 92 lungo di sè di notte furia e calca, 93 pur che i Teban di Bacco avesser uopo,
94 cotal per quel giron suo passo falca, 95 per quel ch’io vidi di color, venendo, 96 cui buon volere e giusto amor cavalca.
query.result:
**English:**
91 And as Ismenus and Asopus once saw 92 by night a crowd and throng of Furies along their banks, 93 just so that the Thebans might have need of Bacchus,
94 so through that circle their pace quickens, 95 because of what I saw of those approaching, 96 whom good will and just love ride.
**Cornish:**
91 Ha kepareth ha Ismenus ha Asopo 92 a welas yn nos furyow ha kalka a-dro dhe'n avonow, 93 rag mayth an Tebesow a wra ow bos Bacco,
94 kepareth dre henna giron an passow a wra ow falka, 95 rag an hansa ow a welas a wra ow tos, 96 neb a wra da volonte hag amor just ow kavalkya.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Tosto fur sovr’ a noi, perché correndo 98 si movea tutta quella turba magna; 99 e due dinanzi gridavan piangendo:
100 «Maria corse con fretta a la montagna; 101 e Cesare, per soggiogare Ilerda, 102 punse Marsilia e poi corse in Ispagna».
query.result:
**English:**
97 Soon they were upon us, because running 98 that whole great crowd was moving; 99 and two in front were crying out:
100 "Mary ran in haste to the mountain; 101 and Caesar, to subdue Ilerda, 102 attacked Marseilles and then rushed to Spain."
**Cornish:**
97 Yn pub o honan wartha, rag ow tos, 98 ow tos an bagas magh oll an bagas brassa; 99 ha dewdh a-rag ow kewsel, ow kanas:
100 "Mary a ros yn fretta dhe'n menydh; 101 ha Cesar, rag sojoga Ilerda, 102 a bannas Marsilia ha ros dhe Spaynek."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 «Ratto, ratto, che ’l tempo non si perda 104 per poco amor», gridavan li altri appresso, 105 «che studio di ben far grazia rinverda».
query.result:
**English:**
103 "Quickly, quickly, so that time is not wasted 104 for a little love," the others shouted after them, 105 "for the effort to do good renews grace."
**Cornish:**
103 "Ratel, ratel, na goller an amser 104 rag lyha karanteth," an bagas erel ow kewsel, 105 "rag studhyans rag ober da gras ow adnewydh."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 «O gente in cui fervore aguto adesso 107 ricompie forse negligenza e indugio 108 da voi per tepidezza in ben far messo,
109 questi che vive, e certo i’ non vi bugio, 110 vuole andar sù, pur che ’l sol ne riluca; 111 però ne dite ond’ è presso il pertugio».
query.result:
**English:**
106 "O people in whom sharp fervor now 107 perhaps makes up for negligence and delay 108 caused by your lukewarmness in doing good,
109 this man who is alive, and certainly I do not lie to you, 110 wants to go up, as long as the sun shines on us; 111 therefore tell us where the opening is nearby."
**Cornish:**
106 "O dus, yn neb ow fervour dowr a-lemmyn 107 a wra dalleth marnas ha lettyans 108 owth eus a-rag eughder yn ober da,
109 hemma ow pew, ha sur na'm gorra lowen, 110 a vynna mos dhe'n ughella, pub may'th an howl ow ri luha; 111 rag henna lavar dhe'n ni wheth yw'n perthugh."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Parole furon queste del mio duca; 113 e un di quelli spirti disse: «Vieni 114 di retro a noi, e troverai la buca.
query.result:
**English:**
112 These were the words of my guide; 113 and one of those spirits said: "Come 114 behind us, and you will find the opening."
**Cornish:**
112 An gerow-ma hemma a'm duga; 113 hag unn a'n spyrysow a leveris: "Dos 114 yn-nestra dhe'n ni, ha kavos an perthugh."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Noi siam di voglia a muoverci sì pieni, 116 che restar non potem; però perdona, 117 se villania nostra giustizia tieni.
query.result:
**English:**
115 We are so full of desire to move on, 116 that we cannot stay; therefore forgive us, 117 if you consider our rudeness to be just.
**Cornish:**
115 Ni yw leun a vynna mos movyans, 116 may nyns yw gallos gorra; rag henna, pardona, 117 mar vyllans ni yw justys dhys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Io fui abate in San Zeno a Verona 119 sotto lo ’mperio del buon Barbarossa, 120 di cui dolente ancor Milan ragiona.
query.result:
**English:**
118 I was abbot in San Zeno in Verona 119 under the rule of the good Barbarossa, 120 about whom Milan still grieves.
**Cornish:**
118 My a veu abbat yn San Zeno yn Verona 119 a-dhyworth an emperour da, Barbarossa da, 120 neb a wra Milan ow kewsel a-dro dhe bys vyth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Io non so se più disse o s’ei si tacque, 128 tant’ era già di là da noi trascorso; 129 ma questo intesi, e ritener mi piacque.
query.result:
**English:**
127 I do not know if he said more or if he was silent, 128 so far had he already passed us by; 129 but this I heard, and I was pleased to remember it.
**Cornish:**
127 My ny wodhaf mar leveris moy po tavas, 128 kemmys o veu mos ow tremena dhyn; 129 mes hemma a glewas vy, ha plas ow kovsa.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 E quei che m’era ad ogne uopo soccorso 131 disse: «Volgiti qua: vedine due 132 venir dando a l’accidïa di morso».
query.result:
**English:**
130 And he who was helping me in every need 131 said: "Turn here: see two of them coming 132 giving a bite to sloth".**Cornish:**
130 Ha henna o vea dhysoqos dhe'm dhe pub traus 131 a leveris: "Treylyma: gweles dew 132 ow tos ow tos dhe'n akkedhi a'n morso".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Di retro a tutti dicean: «Prima fue 134 morta la gente a cui il mar s’aperse, 135 che vedesse Iordan le rede sue.
query.result:
**English:**
133 Behind all of them they were saying: "Before 134 the people to whom the sea opened up died, 135 Jordan saw its banks".**Cornish:**
133 Wosa dhe bub traus o leveris: "A-rag 134 marow an bobel dhe'n mor a dhyskleris, 135 Iordan a welas y redew ytho".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 E quella che l’affanno non sofferse 137 fino a la fine col figlio d’Anchise, 138 sé stessa a vita sanza gloria offerse».
query.result:
**English:**
136 And she who did not suffer the hardship 137 until the end with the son of Anchises, 138 offered herself to a life without glory".**Cornish:**
136 Ha henna na'n sofferis an affan 137 bys dhe'n diwedh gans mab Anchise, 138 y honen dhe hwegen dhe byw heb glori".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 Poi quando fuor da noi tanto divise 140 quell’ ombre, che veder più non potiersi, 141 novo pensiero dentro a me si mise,
142 del qual più altri nacquero e diversi; 143 e tanto d’uno in altro vaneggiai, 144 che li occhi per vaghezza ricopersi,
145 e ’l pensamento in sogno trasmutai.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Then when those shades were so far divided 140 from us that we could see them no more, 141 a new thought came into me,
142 from which many others were born and diverse; 143 and I wandered so much from one to another, 144 that I covered my eyes out of desire,
145 and I transformed my thought into a dream.**Cornish:**
139 Pan wosa an ombres henna kemmys o dhyskleris 140 dhyworthyn, na'n galleughom gweles moy, 141 nowyth poynt a dheuth dhe'm dhe-ves,
142 a-dhyworth henna moy a dheuth moy erel, 143 ha kemmys a vanegis dhyworth unn dhe unn, 144 wosa'm dhe'm dhe'n golghi dhe'm dhe-ves,
145 ha'm dhe'm dhe'n poynt dhe dreus dhe hunv.
